By the year 2022 the US government, led by our New Founding Fathers, has managed to crawl its way out of a triple dip recession and record crime rates. Unemployment stands at 1%, and crime is at an all time low. With one exception. Once a year, on a date designated as The Purge, for twelve hours all crime is legal. Rape, murder, theft, the entire US has a free pass to do whatever they wish and suffer no repercussions for it. In a single day thousands are murdered and millions of dollars worth of property destroyed in order to give everyday American's an outlet to vent their rage, anger, and frustrations in the hope that they will "cleanse their souls" and not be tempted to commit crimes for the rest of the year.

First of all let's put aside the fact that the premise at face value makes absolutely no sense. I'll let that slide, though I do feel it needs to be said. The premise is what it is, and as implausible as it is, I still thought it interesting enough to warrant a look. But even overlooking  this, the movie has some serious flaws that I felt wasted what could have been a very intelligent film. First of all, this film is produced by the same people who brought us great horror movies like the Paranormal Activity movies, Insidious and Sinister, and while I loved those movies this film should have been different. The premise screams suspense thriller, as instead of dealing with supernatural beings like in their previous films, the main baddies in this one are a bunch of teenagers in masks and an old homeless man. To put it simply, there is nothing even remotely scary about this movie, so the fact that they filmed it like a horror movie with the typical horror movie tropes, jump scares, loud music, etc  only served as a distraction both for the director and the audience from what should have been the main focus. These sort of things worked for Sinister and Insidious because of their supernatural elements, because the villains were invisible, evil forces that couldn't be talked to or reasoned with. This film doesn't have that. Instead we have some homeless guy wandering around an inexplicably enormous house for an hour while the idiot family that lives there stumbles around in the dark. Am I honestly supposed to be scared by this? The Purge is a thriller in a horror movies clothing, and ultimately in my opinion fails horribly at being either.

But what about The Purge itself? Do we get to see the streets turn into battle grounds? Is there subtle yet engaging social commentary to go along with such an interesting premise? Sadly, no. I don't know what these producers deal is with filming well off families in big houses, but this story should have really been told from the POV of someone who is poor and, thus, unable to afford protection from the roaming bands of psychotic rich kids trying to kill them. This is what should have been the focus of the film, not some boring rich family with first world problems, but the poor and downtrodden who are the real victims of this sick tradition. Imagine a film where a poor, single mother/father flees with their children from bands of killers who are not only allowed to kill at will, but encouraged to do so as well. That would have been a great movie. Instead we get boring suburban dad with boring suburban wife, and boring suburban kids. Nothing gets my heart strings strumming like privileged rich people trying to throw some poor homeless guy to the wolves. Yeah, I feel real sorry for those guys.

The Purge is a film that had a great idea but no idea how to see it through. Its boring, badly directed, and commits the cardinal sin of being a horror movie that isn't even remotely scary. If you really want to see it, wait until its on netflix and stream it. Otherwise, my suggestion is to pass. Its really not worth the effort.

In an idealized future version of America, we vent our national frustration on one golden night, in which all crime up to and including murder is legal and the results are somehow televised. Apparently it works, because violence is supposedly down and employment is way up, but there is the tricky issue of surviving that single naughty holiday without passing through the crosshairs of an enemy. As a concept, The Purge is ripe. Especially so today, four years after its release, when the nation seems as politically and culturally divided as ever and violent undercurrents are simmering. There's so much opportunity to toy with the metaphorical overtone (including one or two extra-interesting caveats about the event itself which are left unexplored) that it's amazing they're merely used to prop up a rather generic horror/suspense combo. Family makes a series of poor choices. Bad guys show up on their doorstep to make threats and embrace modern horror stereotypes. Big showdown with a few telegraphed twists. That's the jist. The allure of the Purge, and the nationwide embrace of what it means, is right there, just begging to be further mined, but instead it's relegated to mere background color. An excuse not to call the police, really, and nothing more. Despite an inspired (and, go figure, largely unexplored) take by Rhys Wakefield as the charismatic gang leader, this is some bland, uniform stuff.

The fact that you decide to kill doesnt make you invincible. Therefore, to simply walk in the street is just plain stupid. You can get shot from a distance anytime. The killers that we follow act like no one in the house is armed. They simply enter and roam around, dancing, singing, without protecting themselves. And in a situation like the purge, why are bands of tugs trusting each other? A lot of those plot holes could have been avoided with a simple line or a simple scene here and there. To conclude, the suspense is certainly fun, the theme is interesting as a metaphor but too many dumb and questionable situations and intentions are ruining everything.

This was a fantastic horror movie, with an interesting premise. I really enjoyed watching it and was certainly rooting for the family the movie is centered around. The franchise should have stayed more closely to this original film.

The unique angle of this film isn't really delved into other than setting up for your standard home invasion film which ultimately is a pretty weak and not that interesting one compared to Straw Dogs (original version), Fear and well most films in this genre. There didn't even really seem to be any real motivation to why those outside would risk their lives storming a fortified building when they don't know what weapons (or even people) await them inside.  I was waiting for some big reveal that the homeless guy, wasn't just a homeless guy or Ethan Hawke's character, his daughter, wife or someone had actually done something that means they need to be killed during this opportunity, but nothing like that was ever revealed.  Surely there were plenty more other people that could be purged outside they could find during the time they waste waiting to be handed this particular one.

The action on the streets of America under the whole, all crime is legal for 12hours, was what the movie needed to concentrate on.  There's two sequels to this film and even though I found this film extremely disappointing, I find the 12 hour purge concept interesting enough that I'll check them out.  I just hope we actually delve into it in those sequels.  For example I was wondering why you wouldn't just go on a holiday each year on the date of the purge to Canada, Europe, well wherever isn't America. Surely that would be cheaper than getting a security system installed.  The only reason I could see this couldn't happen would be if Americans aren't allowed to travel overseas anymore and are shot trying to cross the border or sneaking away on boats or whatever. If they can still travel does America not extradite citizens to face charges for crimes that occur on the date of a purge?  I also wondered what happens with hospitals?  Surely they would be immune, but then again the sick and weak being removed from society were one of the reasons for the purge. So do staff just walk away from the hospital until the siren sounds when it should be safe to return?  If it is immune wouldn't thousands of people just flock there?  There's just so many holes in the concept of the yearly purge that aren't addressed in this film.

Plus why would you spend all this money on a security system that has no emergency lighting or even a generator if the power is cut?  Wouldn't you have some strategic points in the house you could set up to hide behind while you can fire on those coming through the entrance? Wouldn't your security system come with heavily armed response security that you could also call if people were trying to get in?  Especially when the whole street has the same security company system installed.

For me the sheer stupidity of the family members made this hard viewing.  The son (who I actually thought was a little girl before he spoke) disabling the security system then never grasping the whole, if your family don't find him they're going to be all wiped out concept. Why did the daughter run off to other parts of the house, when obviously safety would have been with her family.  How big is this house that doesn't look that huge from the outside, be that you can't find people for ages?

As I said the concept of the yearly purge intrigues me enough to check out the sequels, but I can't say I'd bother recommending this first movie to anyone, when there's so many better home invasion alternatives out there.

This family acts as if it's the first time this allowed violence has happened,  It's the EIGHTH time, in eight years,  They have a beautiful upper story that would have made a fantastic sniper's nest.  The house had the high ground, but no fence at all.  The creepy idiots that went after the family mainly had melee weapons; half were dressed in what seemed like nightgowns. For that matter, since murder is legal for this night, why did they even let them step one foot on the property?  Take 'em out right away- no problem.
The few intruders that had guns mainly had shotguns or handguns.  Again, nothing a good sniper couldn't handle, especially with the high ground.
Oh, and they have a state of the art surveillance system, which would have been great, if they had some one to man it, instead of being away from the console most of the time.
Except for the father, most of the other family members didn't seem to have too much training with their weapons.  If the purge were the case, I'd have the family at the range at least once a week.  Plus, he has a very nice assortment of weapons to choose from, and what does he take?  A six shot revolver.  There was at least one scoped rifle and a shotgun in there, if I'm recalling correctly.
Why didn't they have floodlights to blind intruders and a couple of large well trained dogs? Before you get upset, I don't condone the idea, but we're going with the extreme scenarios now.)

There are so many other things wrong, I could write a novel about it, but if you want to take a chance, do it.  I'd actually recommend you watch the second and third purge movies instead.  They're marginally better.

I love horror movies but The Purge was so much more than just scary. The movie said a lot about social injustice and clearly sends a message about human nature in the present.

Given the shrill, overbaked, hyperbolic language that passes for debate between the Right and the Left these days, it's no wonder that the best place to address politics in film may be the horror genre.

Enter writer-director James DeMonaco's The Purge, a genuinely tense, effective home-invasion thriller starring Ethan Hawke ( The Woman in the Fifth) and Lena Headey ( Game of Thrones) that opens Friday.

A genre picture on its grisly, gritty outside, The Purge tries, not always successfully, to mount a critique of America's culture of violence and our growing obsession with wealth, which according to the film, has robbed us of our last shreds of compassion and empathy.

Heavy-handed? Perhaps, but the film is surprisingly effective.

The Purge is set in an alternate America that has solved its economic problems by instituting an annual ritual called the Purge: For 12 hours beginning at 7 p.m. every March 21, Americans are free to commit any crime. There will be no cops, ambulances, or fire engines on the streets, and no prosecution will follow once the dust settles.

The Purge saves America! It reduces unemployment and gets the economy going in a brutally efficient way: Once a year, the country is cleansed of all the poor, destitute, weak people who can't take care of themselves, all the parasites who live off the government's largesse.

It's Social Darwinism gone wild.

Hawke and Headey are very good as an upper-middle-class couple who made their money selling elite security systems - like the rest of the upper-crust, they can shut out the Purge with heavily fortified walls.

Things go horribly wrong when their son Charlie (Max Burkholder) gives in to empathy and lets a homeless drifter (Edwin Hodge) hide in the house. The film goes from tense to psychotic when a group of prep school kids lays siege to the house, demanding they be allowed to kill the drifter. Should the family protect the weak, or turn him out?

DeMonaco sneaks in the film's political message using RoboCop director Paul Verhoeven's tried-and-true method: The action is foregrounded against a constant stream of news reports, talk shows, and public-service ads, including "Purge Feeds," live footage of gangs of hunters killing and torturing fellow human beings. The dead are eulogized for their "sacrifice."

In its own clumsy, exaggerated way, The Purge takes a strong stand against our cultural obsession with violence and our tendency to conflate justice with vengeance.

In what is easily one of the most inventive and interesting premises recent memory, the 'New Founding Fathers" have instituted an annual 12-hour holiday that they call "The Purge". during the Purge all crime including murder is made legal (with the exception of high ranking government officials of course). The film toys with some big ideas including how this keeps our current system of income inequality in place as the rich get an opportunity to kill off the poor and homeless, thus keeping tension off the social safety net. This could have been a truly interesting exploration of systemic racism and class warfare...but instead it squanders it's promise and becomes a typical home invasion movie.

The cast lead by Ethan Hawke, Lena Headey and a villianous Rhys Wakefield do a fine job with the material. This is especially true of Wakefield, who is delightfully creepy and hammy. The two child actors in the film, as well as the homeless man at the center of the conflict, are all serviceable but are given very little to do.

The story centers around Hawke and Headey's family as they lock down and settle in to ride out the Purge in relative safety. There is a quickly abandoned subplot with the eldest daughter and her boyfriend that is resolved and has next to no bearing on the rest of the film. The movie then devolves into a snooze-fest as the main cast attempt to find a homeless man in the dark for 20 minutes in order to escape the wrath of a group of wealthy young purgers led by Wakefield. When time runs out the film picks up some steam before it's anticlimactic denouement.

What does this movie shows? It shows that a security system with concrete walls is useless when your enemy brings a truck with a cable to pull off that wall. It's also heartening that a family full of people that didn't want to purge ended up purging. Of course, it wasn't senseless violence but self-defense.

With that said, it's unrealistic to think that making all crime legal for 12-hours a year would lower the crime rate. If you're a drug dealer, you're dealing when you have merchandise, you're killing your competitors/enemies when they get in your way. What the Purge movie seems to be saying is that law-abiding people can't wait to become criminals. That good old frat boys can't wait to murder and rape, that behind ever upstanding member of society hides a savage waiting to get out, and by allowing him to release the beast once a year, he'll be a nice person the rest of the year.

This concept was pretty unique, at least as far as my movie-viewing experience limits me to. Maybe a film afficienado (sp?) would have a different opinion in that regard, but I was impressed by the creativity.

 Although it sounds ridiculous at face value, the director/actors did a fairly good job at making the main premise- that the government has deemed one night per year a free-for-all for all citizens to commit unlawful acts without any consequence- believable. The reasoning behind why this night came into existence (to allow citizens a chance to take out their inner aggression lawfully in order to prevent them from committing bad acts throughout the rest of the year) makes no real sense, but they sold it pretty well as being logical to the characters in the film.

However, I found the way the plot played out to be a bit over-the-top, a tad too violent to be truly entertaining (I'm not a fan of violence, especially unnecessary gore), and not all that unexpected. I think more twists could have been involved instead of following the basic home invasion film equation in order to match the level of creativity the premise brought to the table. I wouldn't call it a total waste of time, but wouldn't watch it again. I would say it's completely average in all ways but two- the acting and the premise itself. Otherwise, I'm unimpressed

The Purge Universal Pictures 2013 Rated R DVD version
OMG.  Both the front and back cover of the DVD suggested this might be a slasher horror film, catering perhaps to the worst impulse of human nature: sadism.  I was pleased to find it was far better than that, though don't go viewing it expecting to see the next "Gone With The Wind".
Lets start with the basics.  Its rated R and it warrants R due to scenes of violence including murder, though there is no excess unnecessary blood nor scenes of mutilation.  The use of expletives is fairly minimal and of nudity, none (nothing more than you would see on an average beach).
The story takes place in 2022.  That the screenplay must have been written well prior to 2013 and post-2008 and the world-wide financial crisis lends its backstory some credibility.  It still remains plausible today, since the whole world still seems to have financial-withdrawal shakes.  The story takes place entirely in the US, so what has become of the rest of the world is not mentioned.

Early in the film we're told the US went on to experience a financial crisis far worse than 2008 resulting in rioting and virtual anarchy.  Following the next election the new government did a radical re-think of what society needed.  It concluded that since aggression is an essential element of human beings, in order to prevent recurring wars or a constant level of violent crime, some new element in our social fabric was needed.  Thus was born The Purge, a 12 hour period from 7 PM to 7 AM occurring once per year, in which all crimes including murder were permitted (exempting naturally, crimes against government officials above a certain level!)  The theory was that, secure in the notion that they could seek revenge at a later date, people would better control their aggression for the rest of the year.  It had the additional side-effects of eliminating from society those least able to defend themselves and probably also the least productive, lowering unemployment and increasing economic growth.

So the story begins just before the onset of the annual purge in 2022.  The lead couple are good actors: Ethan Hawke as father and Lena Headey as mother of an upper-middle class family in a gated community.  They have a late-teen daughter and an early-teen son who also play prominent roles.  It just so happens that Hawkess character James Sandin was project leader on the latest and greatest in home security systems to defend against the anarchy of the Purge, and they did very well financially in the past year.  Of course they have it installed on their own home too.

In the hour leading up to the purge people seem remarkably sanguine (at least in this gated community, in which everyone has installed security systems.  Even in the last minutes before 7 PM, Sandin and family seem non-credibly calm and nonchalant.  This was the first tremor in the production: I don't care how good a home security system I had, under those circumstances I really don't think I would be preoccupied with watching TV news or running on a treadmill!  Regardless, early on this film plants quite a number of clues to the future plot, some of which pan out true and some of which are red herrings [just see if you can figure out which are which, without being told!]

Theres a part of the fun: seeing how much of the plot you can figure before it unfolds, and how sure you feel about your guesses.  Then compare them to the results!  Guessing who will still be alive and who will have died by the end of the film is only one part of this jigsaw puzzle.

Now let me switch to the downsides of the film.  There is nothing new or spectacularly good about the cinematography.  It was competent.  There was nothing really outstanding about the musical score.  It seemed to be tense and brooding to one degree or another pretty much throughout, but was unobtrusive.  The acting is good.  The dialog is pretty good.  The editing: ah theres the rub!  At times I felt there was too much aimless wandering back and forth in the house and cutting from scene to scene, which I suppose was meant to illustrate a familys confusion in an unexpected situation and the chaotic nature of unfolding events, but at times all this did was annoy me as a viewer.  I think the film would have been improved by more careful editing of the scenes to prune away what was annoying without contributing to the story.

Overall as I watched, I was surprised how much this film resonated with Night of the Living Dead by Romero.  Not that there were any zombies in this movie, because there are not.  Rather, both the general structure of the scenes and in the underlying issues it poses to a viewer are much like NOLD.  People trapped in a house?  Check.  A black person among whites?  Check.  Therefore, race relations?  Check.  Economic divides?  Check.  Whether violence or compassion wins out?  Check.
Of course compared to NOLD this has the benefits of a better budget, full-color and higher resolution filming, and more proficient actors.  In short, I felt its a remarkably well-done and thoughtful movie posing as a horror film.  For those who can stomach a tense movie, this is worth watching

The Purge is a kind of movie Ethan Hawke has been doing these days when not working for Richard Linklater. It is a low-budget thriller with a few nice ideas that could have been executed in a better way. It is not that the film is a terrible mess. It is rather that the film failed to fully exploit its potential as a thriller or political satire.

James DeMonacos The Purge is basically a home invasion thriller like The Desperate Hours, Funny Games and Panic Room. The difference is that the main events take place during the twelve hours of the Annual Purge, when every crime including murder is legalized. The story is set in the near future, when the United States is ruled by a new totalitarian government.

Ethan Hawke plays James Sandin, a successful businessman and family man of two children and wife Mary (Lena Headey). The rich family is going to spend the night of the Purge together in a fancy house protected by a security system  the same one James has sold to the neighbors. A homeless person has managed to get inside the house, however, and that makes Jamess family a target of the gun-wielding strangers.

Writer / director James DeMonaco (writer of remake Assault on Precinct 13 and co-writer of The Negotiator) has intended to make a thriller with a moral message. Thats fine, but the film itself is not as thrilling or insightful as it should, with stock characters making unaccountable decisions, and old hackneyed storytelling devices like criminals taking pause to say something unnecessarily before doing what they do.

As a mindless low-budget thriller The Purge is just OK, though, of course, it wants to be something more than that.

The Purge
 This movie is not worth your time.
 Still with me?  We have a solid cast of young and not so young pros who are very convincing in their roles.  Long time actor Ethan Hawke has the lead as the husband/father in the Sandin family.  He sells security systems for a living, which is a good business because in the future there is an annual holiday which makes all crimes, including murder, perfectly all right.  Hawke, as James Sandin, tries his very best to save his family from the chaos of The Purge.  English actress Lena Headley-who we love to hate as Cersei Lanister in the HBO series Game of Thrones, is his wife Mary.  They have two children, a tween boy played by Max Burkholder and a fifteenish girl played by 22 year old Australian actress Adelaide Kane.  Both the youngsters have already racked up an impressive string of movie, TV and even voice roles.  The acting is quite good all in all.  The older daughter is a brat, a self centered girl who wants only her older-too old- boyfriend.  Her younger brother is a bright but disturbed child doing his best to cope with life.
 The story is preposterous, and I say that after having reviewed Epic, a tale about a girl who shrinks into a world of living flowers and fairies.  We enter the story in year 10 of a period of stability and prosperity enlivened by a once a year killing binge, The Purge.  The opening credits show many, many people being murdered by blunt instrument, by blade, by gun and even by simple beating.  We know just what we are getting into but we have already paid our money.
 The action sequences are harrowing, up close, intense and realistic.  The game father engages a gang of periodic psychopaths in defense of his mate and cubs.  He shoots some of them and beats others to death with pocket pool equipment.  Question for James DeMonaco, the writer/director, if James has known about the night of The Purge for 10 years, why isn't he better prepared?  The family members separate so each can be endangered while all alone.  Who would do that?  A wise family would bond with each other at the shooting range in between the annual bloodletting and be both fierce and armed to the eyeballs.
 The whole thing is too stupid to be enjoyable for me.  But how did this one saw blade disaster manage to get made at all-and by Hollywood professionals mind you, not some film school kids with hand held cameras?  The producer is Michael Bay, the director of the Transformer films and the excellent Armageddon.  He is co-owner of Platinum Dunes, a film production company that specializes in re-making schlock horror flicks like Texas Chainsaw Massacre (2003).  This R (graphic violence) rated film was made on a tiny budget of three million dollars.  It is projected to take in about $20 million in the opening weekend.  I think that answers the question of why was it made.

Crime trends[edit]
Some studies had argued for smaller racial disparities in violent crime in recent times. However, a 2011 study which examined the racial disparities in violent crime and incarceration from 1980 and 2008 found little difference for black share of violent offending. Racial imbalances between arrest rates and sentencing have caused some to question the disparities. The authors argued that the prior studies had been confounded by not separating Hispanics from Whites. The number of Hispanic offenders has been increasing rapidly and have violence rates higher than that of Whites but lower than that of Blacks.[29] Another recent study in 2012 raises a different concern, showing that Hispanics and blacks receive considerably longer sentences for the same or lesser offenses on average than white offenders with equal or greater criminal records.[30][31]

Homicide[edit]

Most murders were intraracial, with 84% of white homicide victims murdered by whites, and 93% of black victims murdered by blacks.[32][33]

It's really too bad that this movie is as preachy and politically correct as it is.  It had real potential.  Even given its shortcomings and idiocies there was still tension, at least early on.

In the near future, after a catastrophic economic breakdown, there's a new, prosperous America that now channels all aggression into an approved 12-hour period once yearly (just how it avoids violence the rest of the year is unsaid).  It's an absurd notion, but go with it because it's an interesting idea.  A rich family, the Sandins, have settled down for the night behind their mansions's steel-protected windows and doors.  Then the morons in the family come to the fore: the 12 or 13-year-old son, who should have been whipped to within an inch of his life, lets in a man who's begging for shelter.  He goes on to other fumblings.  The teenage daughter is a pouty jerk who acts solely as a complicating factor.  And the mother: what can we say about her?  Pistol-whipping would have been too merciful for her babbling and obnoxiousness.

Fair warning: there are spoilers ahead.  There's a gang after the man the boy let in.  Is it a bunch of street thugs after revenge on the rich folks?  Nope, it's a band of well-educated, well-off people off on a Purge Night lark.  Some of them are envious of the Sandins' wealth, so they're going to kill them.  Take that, you capitalist swine!  The refugee is black and homeless, so throw in a parable of wicked white overlords hunting down their proper minority prey.  There's a moment after the bad guys get into the house and have seemingly won, that they then encircle the family and chant some semi-religious mantra that is the logo of the New America.  So there, you religious cranks out there in non-movie America!

The father wants to turn the refugee over to the gang to save his family, but the rest of the family thinks the father's just a monster for even entertaining the idea.  Naturally the man on the run changes the father's heart and he decides to fight.  Now here's a real chestnut in the movie: he arms his son and tells him to hide (of course the idiot son hides in an obvious place with a flashlight on, so he's easily found); the mother looks at her husband and says "You gave a pistol to our son!"  Well, duh.  You're all about to die, and you're upset about the pistol?  The movie just reeks of political correctness.

There are several very predictable deus ex machina moments, where a good guy pops up just in time to shoot the bad guy before he wreaks havoc on a family member.  Ho hum.

The capper is the bonus feature on the making of the film. This movie, like Sinister, had a really good premise.  Too bad about the outcome.  In fact, I think both movies should be called Sinister Purge.  They're both sinister in a bad way and you'll need to purge yourself after viewing both.  Why is it that Hawke seems to be attracted to projects that have an interesting concept, yet just don't deliver?

This movie takes on the interesting topic of reducing societal crime to one night a year in a "new America" so that it's legal for people to commit heinous acts on others they've been itching to do what most people would never do unless they were given that right.  Naturally, that's really not going to work in reality, because if people had to wait a whole year to feed on such awful desires, the suppression would make them explode long before that.  Okay, so we suspend reality, and in the film, you really HAVE to.

You can tell yourself you care about a bunch of rich snobs who can wall up safely behind closed door with a security system while they claim that this annual murder does so much good.  It's hard to swallow that pill when the less off are out there fighting for their self preservation.  Hawk's character is an unlikable jerk who is in the security system business, yet the crappy equipment he's designed doesn't appear to do jack for him and his family.  A family consisting of a frumpy looking, irritating wife (sort of like the shrew he was married to in Sinister, sans the fake, irritating British accent), a silly teenage daughter in a schoolgirl's uniform who you just want to slap because she's so annoying, and a boy who is the only one in the family who seems to have an ounce of compassion for the less off, yet plays with this ugly RC doll in a car incessantly to the point you want to blow the thing up, and has hair at a length that rivals his sister's.  The son in Sinister also had hair to has butt as well, but I guess it was so dark in both films they couldn't tell that either of them needed the Sampson and Delilah treatment.

Little junior lets a homeless guy (well, I guess he is) in off the street at the last minute before he's attacked, and provokes a group of arrogant weirdos, led by a greasy haired, snot-nosed punk (how old is this "menace" anyway, 16?) right up to their "secured" fortress which ironically has no gate around it.  They threaten to come in and kill the whole family if they don't give up the "useless societal dredge" within a certain amount of time, but it's hard to take seriously.  For one thing, nobody in the family is likeable, and for another, the morons out on the lawn with the masks on aren't very scary as they dance around and play on the swings.  Gee, I'm scared.  This is just like watching a bad episode of Gem and the Holograms.  It's truly, truly truly outrageous.

Lots of violence ensues, but there is a surprising twist toward the end--no, wait, it's only surprising if you weren't paying attention to some snide dialogue near the beginning.  Oh, it's so awful to be rich when other rich people buy your product without being forced to.  Sounds like typical Hollywood hypocrisy to me.  Hawkes' character ends up with the same fate as in Sinister, but I won't say so in case you haven't seen that one. Considering I thought Sinister was slightly better, all I can really say in conclusion is that they could have used Mr. Boogie as the adversary here again.  It would have been a whole lot more convincing.

THE PURGE (2012) poses an interesting, wild premise: What if, for a 12-hour period, one had the freedom to commit ANY crime?! That is the story in this unique, provocative, yet flawed film. This movie has gotten a lot of negative reviews, but I'm somewhere in the middle. While it has a few annoyances and frustrating moments, it does a good job of showing who your REAL friends are in this world and when the chips are down, who you perhaps can really count on. The "kindness of strangers" takes on a whole new meaning in this one!

Set in the supposedly not-too-distant future, Hawke persuasively plays James Sandin, a rich suburbanite whose company sells "foolproof" home security systems designed to protect "the haves" against intruders during the annual purge, where the government allows anarchy to prevail for a period of 12 hours. Rampant crime is allowed and no one will be prosecuted as long as they commit their lawless acts within the acceptable timeframe. Sandin and his wife Mary (superbly played by Lena Headey), along with their 2 kids Charlie (Max Burkholder) and Zoey (Adelaide Kane) stay barricaded in their high-tech home, protected by the security system. But things go awry as Charlie spots a bloodied "Stranger" (excellently played by Edwin Hodge) running for his life, and activate the system to let him in. There is another major development (which kind of took me out of the movie for a while) that coincides with this. Then the group of psychotic purgers arrive to bargain with the Sandins to turn over the Stranger.

There are several weak points of the film, most notably the actors playing the Sandin kids. I get that child actors should be allowed some leeway, but they were important to the plot. Also, these 2 characters did extremely frustrating things that caused all the trouble to begin with! Also, that early major development that coincides with the Stranger's arrival was one of the most convoluted things I've ever seen in a movie! I thought it was a cheap way for the director to get across the message, when the latter stages of the film did a more potent job of doing so. Finally, I thought the main purger tormenting the family wasn't very intimidating. A very standard stone-faced, monotone-speaking "movie psycho" character.

Strong performances by Hawke, Headey, and Hodge help keep the film afloat, though. And the ending of the movie kind of helps save it to some degree, as it is very powerful and surprisingly non-cliche. Recommended with some caution!

The basic premise of this film is that one day every year America is immersed in what is known as "The Purge," in the fashion of a holiday. For 12 hours on this day (7PM stretching into the next morning at 7AM), you may commit any crime on the books... but also have said crimes perpetrated on you. For this stretch, there are no police or ambulatory services. A reference to the "New Founding Fathers" is alluded to when this commences in the film. Clearly, there has been some "change" in government.

Ethan Hawke is a super-successful home security salesman who has sold an effective system to all of his neighbors. Their envy for Hawke's wealth is displayed in a ridiculously-obvious manner by writer/director James DeMonaco. I'm not sure if DeMonaco intended this, but when the main characters are poorly written and generally unlikable, how is the viewer supposed to feel any suspense when said characters are at a knife point? Lena Heady plays Hawke's wife and her blithe "The purge does a lot of good" attitude is a terrific example of this. The son is a ghoul who ends up irreversibly dooming the once-secure home for the plot climax and the daughter is a stereotype of angsty teens who "like, TOTALLY like, hates, like everything." The unimaginative, formulaic build-up was bad enough -- then The Purge happens.

No spoilers here, but trust me, you'll want to see this for absolutely free. Anyway, I found the snooty undertones of this "film" to be about as nauseating as Tinseltown's typically-hollow, preachy crap. The film begins with a picture of America 20 years in the future: crime and unemployment are both at an all-time low. However, the 12-hour "purge" is soooooo necessary because people generally have no impulse control and they damn-well need this 12 hour period to settle scores and whack any and all enemies. Anyone else see that this was written by some closet sociopath who actually thinks that anyone with an income under $5 mill will kill at will IF given dispensation to do so?

DeMonaco even goes as far as to feature some "professional" on the tele spouting-off about how violent society is with wars. Correct me if I'm wrong, but aren't the political scum the ones to perpetrate wars and then urge working class people to send their kids to fight said war? "The Purge" would have been far more true to human nature if it were applied to the elite corporate psychopaths (especially in hollywood) who would carve their rivals for even a slight bonus in money and/or fame.

+4 I heard of this movie quite a while before it's theatrical release, and was quite excited about the simple, but compelling premise (All crime- including murder- will be legal for 12 hours.) As often happens I completely forgot about this movie until just today when I saw a preview for The Purge 2: Anarchy. I am pleased to say that this movie did deliver. I thought that The Purge was a suspenseful film with unexpected twists (and I almost always expect them.) The film was well written, and well acted.

-1 star, the one thing that detracted from my overall happiness with The Purge, is the setting. They have taken this amazing new, interesting story and locked it up inside a Panic Room meets Funny Games. Instead of exposing us to the widespread chaos that those 12 hours must bring, we instead are given little more than a home invasion movie. This entire movie could have better served as the backstory for someone setting out to stop, or participate in the next purge. In that, the movie was a disappointment.

Having the advantage of knowing that the sequel will be providing us a larger look at the event, I was able to look past the micro focus, and enjoy the movie.

I remember when the trailer to THE PURGE first came out and the premise was laid out, my good friend Bollywood Bob blurted out: "You mean I could jaywalk all night long and I WON'T GET A TICKET?!" Yes, Bollywood Bob, that's exactly right. During the Purge, you can jaywalk with immunity.

In the year 2022 it's good to be a merchant of home security systems. In 2022 America is experiencing a remarkable era of peace and prosperity. Unemployment stands at 1%. Crime is at an unprecedented low. There's barely a whiff of Violence... except on one scheduled night, when the hooligans and the freaks and the mass murderers come out like sharks circling the water.

March 21, 2022, and sucks for you if you lose track of time. When it strikes 7 o'clock in the evening, you had best be hunkered down in a safe place. Or you'd best be packin'. In this near future, the United States' new founding fathers have instituted the Purge, an annual twelve-hour period in which any crime is legal (and encouraged) and all emergency services are suspended. The working theory is that this state of anarchy serves as a psychological release valve. It's the one night that allows the populace to unleash its pent-up aggression. The movie's premise begs incredulity, but you can't deny its intrigue. And, yeah, it's a fairly novel concept. Note that a STAR TREK episode - "Return of the Archons" - did it first and four decades ago.

3 out of 5 stars for THE PURGE, a film that is half social allegory, half home-invasion thriller. With its nifty hook and its (mostly) good cast, it should've been better than it was. Instead, there are any number of superior home invasion thrillers out there (THE STRANGERS, FUNNY GAMES, PANIC ROOM, WAIT UNTIL DARK). Mostly, THE PURGE is sabotaged by weak execution and by director James DeMonaco's pulling his punches. The result is a tour de blah down the clich factory. Lots of fumbling in the dark. Some anemic scares. Sorry, hopeful gorehound.

On the good side, the social satire comes across as sharply here as it does in, say, THE HUNGER GAMES. It's a premise that provokes thought and triggers some interesting discussions. I like that Ethan Hawke's character, James Sandin, who hawks home security systems, comes off as vaguely scumbaggish. Sandin is a man of his time. As such, he reacts with ingrained apathy and with reflex rationalization towards the atrocities committed during the Purge. It's been drummed into him that the Purge is good for the country. It unburdens the economy, never mind that it achieves this by eradicating the poor, the needy, the defenseless, and whoever else that doesn't contribute to society. His wife Mary (Lena Headey) is equally indifferent. It's hard to rage against something that's made you so rich. James Sandin, who is good at his job, has sold his security system to practically everyone in his affluent, gated community. He decorates his home with blue flowers as a show of support for the Purge. Leave it to their kids to conjure up the elephant in the room - Are they doing the right thing? To which one parent remarks: "Just remember all the good the Purge does, okay? That's all that matters."

Me, I have trouble getting behind horror flicks in which the protagonists usher in their own doom, so there's that. I don't think I'm spoilering things when I say that, yeah, the intruders breach the Sandin household. But did you - as I did - yell at the kid when he did what he did? And did you then check yourself? Because what the kid did was stupid, yes, but he did it from a goodhearted place.

Can this family under siege survive the night without forfeiting their humanity? More importantly, can you stomach this family? Will you find them likable enough to have a rooting interest? Ethan Hawke and Lena Headey deliver steady performances. It doesn't mean their characters are ones that you'd invite over. Or do you chafe under the collar because they're direct reflections of yourself if presented with the same harrowing choices? And I have to say it: The children are super annoying. The eccentric son, Charlie (Max Burkholder), is tapped as the one who asks the hard questions, so there's something to that. But, otherwise, he's such a damp, poorly etched character. The other kid, Zoey (Adelaide Kane), wastes copious screen time either being mopey or stupidly running away or in a state of catatonia. Turns out, the most likable person is the homeless guy (Edwin Hodge). The most interesting person would have to be Rhys Wakefield's creepy but very polite leader of a group of entitled psychopaths.

Quick aside: Doesn't the boy's tricked-out, remote controlled toy tank with the ruined baby doll on top cry out "Hey, contrived plot device over here!" to you?

A SPOILERS alert for this paragraph: For all the good acting work Ethan Hawke puts in, my favorite moment is the pool room scene in which he lets loose and unleashes his inner Straw Dog on a bunch of masked intruders. It's probably the film's highlight action sequence. Hawke does one thing here that is really gratifying. He puts down the intruders and then administers the finishing shots. How often does the good guy not finish off his opponent only to have the creep come back as a last-minute scare?

THE PURGE raked in around $89 million on a $3 million budget. So of course there'll be a sequel and it's almost here. But will it dive as deeply into morality plays and class divides? Me, I'd be cool with a prequel in which we learn more about those game-changing founding fathers and we see what went down during the inaugural Purge.

Just the other day my good friend Bollywood Bob crashed over at my place, and I heard him muttering in his sleep, something about the Purge and the need to "violate, annihilate, and cleanse our souls." I need to scrounge around for some blue flowers. Or a machete.

In 2022, just 8 years from now, the U.S. government has instituted a new holiday. One that has led to peace and prosperity, but at an extreme cost to the less fortunate. For 12 hours, once a year, all crime is legal and people are given the opportunity to release their hatred and rage on anyone they can find. The cast isn't important to a film like this, it's all about the writers cynical message, that behind every smile is jealousy, behind every hand shake is anger, and trust has become a luxury that no one can afford. This Purge is all about the message that is being portrayed, but it has some major holes in the story. If all crime is legal for 12 hours, how come the only thing on peoples mind is murder? There weren't any rapes or bank robberies, nor where there any acts of terrorism or lashing out at authority. It was all about the killing. Most of the Purge is fairly predictable and it is what you would expect it to be. The big surprise comes at the end, which was extremely powerful, and really gives people the opportunity to question the message the writers have portrayed throughout the film. The only notable performance is that of the stars, Ethan Hawke, who was terrific, in a role I really didn't see him fitting into. The Purge is definitely all about the authors agenda and it is somewhat predictable, but what made the film for me, was the terrific ending, which really does give the audience the chance to challenge the cynical nature of the film.

I do!  I believing in doing good things!  Good things that help people!  The Purge shows viewers the impossible law passing that allows 12 straight hours of committing crimes exactly one day out of the year.  It's legal!  Now at first I wasn't sure what kind of crimes the movie was going for.  I figured it meant petty things such as robbing a cashier man at the downtown convenience store or stealing food in a grocery store.  No!  This is a supposed law being passed that allows murder and rape!  What, really?  COME ON!

Now of course, you can imagine due to the many low ratings here on amazon, many people dislike the concept and question its basis on reality.  No, it's not realistic at all.  I personally think the biggest crime this movie committed is calling itself a horror movie.  It's not really horror in the sense that ghosts and aliens torture people out of their homes.  That doesn't happen.  It's definitely more suspenseful than anything.

Let me mention the flaws, of which there's many (and you probably knew I was going to mention them since it's unavoidable not to notice, hehe).

- Why did it seem like hours before the scheduled purging got underway, the rich suburban neighborhood didn't seem to feel nervous in any way?  Regardless how well protected you are with firearms and regardless how modern and sturdy your installed security system is, wouldn't you at least be *somewhat* nervous?  Wouldn't you show at least a little concern?  We're talking about the strong possibility of death here or at the very least property destruction of some kind, and the family the movie in this movie has a younger son and a teenage daughter.  Isn't it human nature to be scared to death and DREAD this day?  Wouldn't you want to be extra cautious with your kids?  But... these parents didn't seem to care.  It's apparently just another walk down the sidewalk with Beaver and Wally in this neighborhood.

- Let's say those willing to commit murder give in to their sadistic ways since they have a 12-hour window to do so.  Without releasing spoilers, what would stop a man from killing someone a few minutes after the 12 hours are up?  Especially if you go through the kind of torment this family does and murder almost seems necessary to survive.  It's not like the FBI and cops would be able to notice that you committed a crime by only a few minutes after the times up!  Then again if such a law is passed that allows murder, the cops and FBI are probably not too concerned about the day after anyway since it's too much law-breaking to handle at once.

- Why did the family NOT stay in their protected firearm-loaded room the entire time the purge was occurring?  The daughter gets up and leaves because hanging out with her parents is apparently lame... and the son does too... and the parents do nothing to stop them!  I'd be like "Where do you think you two are going?  Get back here and sit with your mother and me for 12 hours while we wait and watch the camera filming the outside front yard!"  Hey, they could even make it a family night.  It's not like America has any of those anymore anyway.  :)

With all that said, as a movie -a suspense- I'm willing to overlook the obvious flaws and the silly premise and just enjoy it.  While it does bring up a noticeable but never directly stated point that moral issues seem to be tossed aside these days just for the purpose of passing another law, I'd like to think America would *never* go down the path of allowing murders to happen one day out of the year for 12 hours.  This would be the worst possible thing ever, and anybody with a conscience should immediately realize how ridiculous this would be if true.

The fictional storyline itself is just outrageous with MANY twists and turns.  In fact I'm only going to reveal one part, and that's when the younger son is watching the camera footage of his front yard on a TV in his backroom showing a man running, screaming and begging for someone to open the doors and let him inside.  He's begging for his life because a gang of highly unusual murder-happy young adults wearing masks and carrying guns are determined to take advantage of the purging (and basically worship this day) so they are going around targeting homeless people, which this man happens to be.

The boy (played by Max Burkholder from the awesome drama Parenthood) lets him inside believing the man's really running for his life... and right after this all sorts of chaos ensues when the gang realizes the family is hiding the homeless man inside their tightly locked home, BUT... I consider none of the events that take place from here on out predictable for storyline purposes.  At least two MAJOR twists happen, maybe even three.  People you think are the bad guys suddenly turn good in the heat of the moment and vice versa, and the deaths themselves happen to be incredibly graphic.  The mother reluctantly holding a firearm as she roams the dark hallways assuming that nothing would go wrong is a good moment (or perhaps this is all unintentional and she's actually acting poorly in her role- ha, I hope not- would make me look like a big fool for complimenting her!)

The story mostly focuses on the father wanting to protect his family from the gang of misfits that hang around their front yard and threaten to break into their home with back-up vehicles capable of destroying the security around the family's front door if they don't release the homeless man to them (who's now hiding somewhere in this dark, overlarge house and nobody knows where he is).  Here's the real kicker- the main guy from the gang happens to be exceptionally screwy in the head because to prove how serious he is about potentially murdering the family, he turns his gun to the man next to him who he claims is his best friend, and shoots/kills him.  Wow, even if the family WERE able to find and hand over the homeless man, would you seriously be willing to open the front door and take a chance that you won't eat a bullet for your troubles?  I certainly wouldn't trust the guy from that gang.  He just killed his friend!  He proved he's no more than a crazy lunatic himself.

This movie is really crazy.  Thankfully we can all sleep easy knowing that such an annual purging ordeal would never really happen... right?  *waves tiny American flag and nervously sings God Bless America more convincingly than ever before* :)

I know if I was in this situation I'd create a sturdy, well-protected backroom containing a variety of guns, much like the ones the family has in this movie that they mostly neglected to use, and I'd stay there wide awake the whole night shaking and waiting for anything unusual to come through that door... and then I'd react accordingly.  I'd only shoot if I felt my life was in danger.  Hopefully that's what most people would do because actually taking advantage of such a crime-filled night by going through with the committing of them should make you feel really bad and empty inside.  You're now soulless!

I can't help but think there's many different ways to create a storyline out of a 12-hour crime spree.  Instead of creating a suburban rich family hiding and protecting themselves, they could have shown people with less money and resources scared for their lives in the main part of a city, and we could watch THEIR situations develop.  Or perhaps somewhere out in the country such as a farm in Kansas.  Or maybe Florida near Key West.  Or how about the snowy mountains of Alaska?  So many possibilities.

At least the movie does several things right.  It's quality entertainment for one thing, and it's a storyline I've never encountered in a movie before so I feel it's somewhat original.  The parents -despite not feeling as much concern as they should concerning the safety of their children and their own safety thanks to the apparent confident belief that they're safe and sound in their suburban rich home- are good enough actors/actresses.  At least they're willing to die for their kids.  It's Max's character I like the most.  Him and his little remote control car with a red-eyed camera hidden inside turns out to be such a nifty, case-cracking tool!

The ending has its problems though.  I mean now that it's all out in the open (*ahem!* I'm not spoiling what it is!) why take a chance and let it... fade away like nothing happened?  And return to normal after all that?  You can't.  You'd now be watching your back all day/everyday.  You have to finish it.  Finish it by packing your things, leaving and never coming back again.

When I first saw commercials for THE PURGE, it looked like every other home-invasion survival horror film that's been produced over the last several years; gleeful homicidal maniacs wearing creepy masks break into the home of a wealthy white-bread family, and the family has to fight them off. And with Ethan Hawke, one of the more overrated actors currently working, as the star, it had even less attractive qualities to me. But after reading about the concept behind the film, I decided to give writer/director James DeMonaco's film a try, because from a high-concept standpoint, THE PURGE sounded quite exciting.

Well, the concept is still exciting, but the film doesn't get beyond the lowest-common-denominator garbage that it always looked like.

In the United States of the not-too-distant future, poverty and crime are at all-time lows thanks to a group known as The New Founding Fathers (which we never see or hear about in specifics) who are now running the country. To offset the crippling economy and extreme criminality that had plagued the country just prior to the Fathers coming into power, they institute "The Purge", a 12-hour period of time where all crime, especially violent crime, is not only legal, but encouraged. At the heart of this film is the Sandin family (Hawke and Lena Headey as the parents, Adelaide Kane and Max Burkholder as the kids). James (Hawke) is a salesman of home security systems, and thanks to the Purge, he's become very successful. Mary (Headey) seems to be a stay-at-home mom, Zoey (Kane) is the mid-teen daughter seeing the older boy her father forbids her to see, and Charlie (Burkholder) is the tween son with a brain, playing with his remote-controlled tank/creepy doll-head. It's the day of the Purge, and they lock down their home for the night, but a homeless man (Edwin Hodge) outside is allowed in the home by the naive Charlie, and a pack of young preppy killers led by Rhys Wakefield (whose character credit is Polite Leader) demand that the Sandins release the "filthy homeless man" to their murderous urges, or they will smash down the barricades their house has and kill everyone. Morality and the protective urges are at conflict, but as you can predict, the preppies with their creepy masks and sing-song lunacy enter and the Sandins have to make a stand.

Never mind that the second and third acts of the film play out almost exactly as you would think they would, aside from a moronic and telegraphed 11th-hour "twist". Never mind that everything that DeMonaco does with this film, from a visual standpoint, is totally uninspired and uninteresting. Never mind that the performances in the film are of the check-cashing variety, and that the members of the Sandin family are, naturally, morons in this situation. And never mind that James Sandin is a totally moral vacuum of a protagonist; how are we supposed to root for a man whose livelihood has been considerably improved by this event? If that was all the film was going to be, then it could have literally been recycled from dozens if not hundreds of the same type of film over the past several years. What really annoys me is the utter waste of a really powerful social, political and economic commentary that this film all but squanders by focusing on just this one incident with these specific people. If DeMonaco, who also wrote the abysmal remake of John Carpenter's ASSAULT ON PRECINCT 13 as well as the totally unwatchable werewolf horror-romance, SKINWALKERS, decided to focus more on building a world that these characters inhabit rather than just going to the cheap adrenaline rush of the home-invasion thriller, he might have had something really special. For instance, poverty and homelessness are potentially at such a low rate because it's the homeless and poor people that are being murdered on the night of The Purge. Where are the objectors to this idea? There can be no level of economic calamity and criminal brutality that would be so hopeless that everyone across America believes that The Purge is the solution. Who are the New Founding Fathers? What is their agenda? Is America a totalitarian state now? None of these ideas are explored in this film, other than the question of the homeless people, which is given nothing more than a perfunctory explanation.

So, bad performances, bad script, bad direction all surrounded by a great idea makes THE PURGE an even more painful viewing experience. There's a very interesting film trapped somewhere in THE PURGE, but it's unlikely we'll ever see it.

I'm sure most of you know the plot.. one night a year, American's get to completely purge their souls of evil by going on a criminal binge. All things are legal, chaos erupts in the streets, no police, no firemen, no hospitals, all of the systems put in place to protect you on a daily basis are gone. And anyone and everyone who wants to take a shot at you has an opportunity to do so - and there isn't a damn thing you can do about it except fight back.

So, with a very horrifying concept in hand, what do we get? We get to see a bunch of rich people fight other rich people inside a house. Yea. A massive, nation-wide concept of horror and chaos... we get to experience it condensed into one house. One family. A wealthy family, who can afford protection, who would have undergone ZERO risk except for their own ignorance, find themselves embroiled in a Keeping up with the Jones' style mess. Basically we get an overly dramatic version of Panic Room... Panic Room may have been better.

Now, I know some of your artsy types are going to talk about the expression of morals, or the juxtaposition of classes or the ironic motif etc. Blah, blah. Who cares. The point is this. It was an absolutely fantastic concept, truly one I looked forward to seeing. It was marketed correctly, the opening scenes set it up correctly, and then someone suffered brain damage and ruined the rest.

I was excited to see this movie as I love thriller types like this. For the first half of the movie I genuinely enjoyed it. Maybe 4 star liked it. The idea of a Purge day and the process behind it was a twisted idea, but had great potential for movie of this sorts with many "What would you do?" type scenarios. But as the film continued on, it started to lose its thrill. The reasons being:

- I couldn't understand the Son's thoughts...during the purge or life in general. He comes off as not understanding the horror/reason behind the purge - which is understandable. Heck, the adults were a little foggy on the concept. But we are left hanging as to whether or not he agrees/disagrees by the end - even though some of the movies major events circled around him. Maybe some people don't care about what he thinks. But seeing how he was the reason the stranger got in the house, he's the reason the stranger was protected, and he's the reason all hell broke loose at their house... I kinda think his "motive" is important!

- What the hell happened to the stranger?!?! So in the beginning he is let in the house. Then through 75% of the movie he's in hiding. Okay. Cool, I guess. Whatever. Then out of nowhere at the end he just pops up and is like "Heeeeey - saved your life!" and becomes the hero. Seriously?

- What the hell happened to the daughter?!?! Same thing as the stranger, she starts off as a major part in the movie. After her boyfriend goes batshit she just disappears somewhere in the house. Never to be seen until the end again.

- Last but certainly not least, was the mother's "hysterics" acting. It drove me nuts. Who looks for a killer(s) in their house with their eyeballs plastered on the ground while holding a gun ready for a shoot out. The entire time she's scared and hunting for killers in her house she is seriously staring at the floor, crying, carrying a gun. Meanwhile killers 1-6 are right in front of her - literally 2 feet away - and she doesn't see them because she's staring at the floor!! Common sense, people!

Anyways, that's what I thought. It was entertaining but there were a lot of questions about why the characters were being so stupid as well as why characters seemed to evaporate into thin air up until the major sequence at the end.

You know, the concept behind this film was great: each year, some time in the near future, U.S. laws have changed so that complete lawlessness is allowed on one day of the year. Everything that follows from this concept, in the imagined version of the U.S., is fascinating: companies have swooped in to provide security for people who want to hide in their homes during the purge, and those who go out breaking laws have become vaguely cultish in their once-annual killing sprees.

Okay, so it's a cool concept that really gets you thinking about a slightly alternative way of dealing with deviance.

But what the film becomes is more of an "I'm trapped in my house with psychos trying to get in!" type of thing. 90% of the film focuses just on one family (Ethan Hawke's crew) and how they deal with 1) an intruder, and 2) a bunch more intruders thirsty to kill them. So it's a big bloody mess by day break, and even some jealous neighbors get in on the act.

So here's the problem: what happens in this movie is that the really cool and interesting part -- the notion of US becoming governed by a pressure-release killing day -- gets under examined so that we can sit there watching a home invasion movie. Blah. A good idea poorly executed, I say.

UPDATE: I think the sequel to this film is even better than this original. It covers way more ideas about this great societal concept of control through release.

Laughable in excess and poorly executed, the 2013 horror film "The Purge" is still an interesting take on the most terrifying of occurrences -- the home invasion crime. Such atrocities have been detailed in far more disturbing works including Michael Haneke's Funny Games, Stanley Kubrick's A Clockwork Orange (likely the great inspiration for this film) and Sam Peckinpah's Straw Dogs (Unrated Version). Writer and director James DeMonaco has a good idea, but his film soars off the rails during the frantic second half. It could have been so much more. In the year 2022, the United States is amazingly crime free thanks to an annual event known as "The Purge," a demented Halloween rendering Shirley Jackson's The Lottery a low-key picnic. It is the one night of the year when residents can commit any crime they wish including murder, with the nation's police taking the evening off. Such a holiday allows American residents to vent their rage without fear of incarceration. James Sandin (Ethan Hawke) has made a comfortable living selling home security systems protecting well-to-do families from purge criminals. He pulls up to his beautiful home, the kind of picturesque structure one would see next to the par-5 at a country club, and has dinner with his attractive family, including wife Mary (Lena Headey) and his two truculent teenagers (Adelaide Kane, Max Burkholder). Naturally, the Sandin's home has the state-of-the-art security system. As the purge alarm sounds, a sort of tornado warning siren, James presses a button and huge metal doors slide down to cover the structure. With security cameras surrounding the house, the Sandin family kicks back to watch the "fun." At this point, the film loses it. DeMonaco has assembled a terrific cast for the family, and each actor gives an earnest performance. Hawke especially has evolved into one of the best actors working today. Perhaps not destined for superstar status, his fine work raises "The Purge" several notches, akin to his great performance in the recent horror classic Sinister. I don't have a problem with events ratcheting up the suspense, including an injured African-American man (Edwin Hodge) who runs into the neighborhood begging for help. He's being chased by a fiendish gang of Caucasian college students adorned in costumes, masks and machetes. You see, the dirty secret of the purge is low-income residents cannot afford security systems, and thus are the main targets during the night of murder -- a sort of final solution conveniently cleansing the land of poverty. This thrill-kill cult is led by an unblinking, sadistic ring leader (Rhys Wakefield) with all the subtlety of Charles Manson -- a character so over the top he capsizes the entire film. For multiple reasons, they surround the Sandin's home and prepare to break in, leading to the film's best scene when Hawke's James admits his security system is not foolproof, serving more as a deterrent. The film enters the neighborhood of dull routine as every person with a gun can fire with deadly expertise, and the method the cult breaks in is akin to Tonto pulling down jail bars with nothing more than a horse and rope. For reasons not entirely clear, the family is separated throughout the spatial house with hallways as endless as Kane's Xanadu. Less is more with material like this, but DeMonaco does not trust his audience. If you're going to film an analogy exposing a flawed society consumed with repressed violence, don't embrace the mayhem for box office appeal. He's created some interesting characters. Why force them into implausibility and derivative shoot-outs?

Much better than expected. Based on the previews I kind of expected America after the Purge to be a panacea with a couple of exceptions, and was prepared to be disgusted. That was only the previews, however-- the clear undertones suggest that a whole lot of people have been duped by a small number of powerful and influential politicians; many people are truly uncomfortable with it, and the rest are swayed by a relentless propaganda campaign.

Additionally, it becomes clear quite early that the goal of the Purge is not to "get your violence out" like the propaganda suggests, but it is explicitly to get rid of the undesirables-- the poor, the unemployed, the homeless. This is where it gets viciously good-- the "purgers" see it as their right to eliminate people they don't like and get a truly perverse pleasure in the fact they are allowed, or even encouraged, to do so by their own government. Their leader, Australian actor Rhys Wakefield, is magnificent as the charming psycopath in a suit who could kill people tonight and sell mutual funds tomorrow.

There are a couple of disappointments-- for instance, for all the hype for the latest security system, how easy it ultimately was to break in (Panic Room this isn't, unfortunately); the overuse of the last-second rescue from out of nowhere; a couple of plot lines that fizzled or seemed pointless.

However, all in all I have been recommending it. The directing is tight, the creepy scenes are really, truly, creepy, and there are a couple of surprises in the mix as well. I give it 7/10 and 4/5.

The Purge (2013) **
D: James DeMonaco
C: Ethan Hawke, Lena Headey, Max Burkholder, Adelaide Kane, Edwin Hodge, Rhys Wakefield, Tony Oller, Arija Bareikis
P: In 2022, under a nation reborn, with crime & unemployment at an all time low, an annual purge is held in which it is legal to commit any and all crimes, including murder.

On one hand, The Purge is thought provoking and the type of film that will get people talking. Would you participate in the purge? What kind of activities would you or those that you know of engage in during a purge? What would we do for safety if you decided to stay in? Would you band up with your neighbors? Could you even trust your neighbors?

The idea that in trying to be above it all, the film's protagonist becomes savages in of themselves by trying to protect their home is intriguing. There's also a surprising plot twist in the film's final act. Critics and audiences alike have debated about whether the film is able to fully take advantage of its ingenious concept. Whether The Purge fully took advantage of this idea isn't my issue with the film.

My problem with The Purge is that the film mistakes sudden gun blasts for genuine suspense. My problem with The Purge is that their isn't enough teasing & taunting between the protagonist and the antagonist. If there was a purge occurring, if my home was being invaded, some of the emotions I would feel during that time would be fear, apprehension, tension, unease, confusion, disorientation, claustrophobia, etc. - emotions I never once felt while watching this film. That's definitely a problem. My problem with The Purge is that it lacks an understanding of how to craft suspense, terror and panic. Instead, melodrama involving the main characters takes the forefront distracting from the film's main event- The Purge.

Writer / director James DeMonaco knows how to make a good story. He just doesn't know how to tell it, stage it or properly execute it. [R] 85 mins.

THE PURGE recalls immediately important works, like the classic short shorty by Shirley Jackson THE LOTTERY, and THE HUNGER GAMES as well.  Unlike those works of literature, THE PURGE is all horror movie clich, plot holes, and video game killings.  Like THE LOTTERY and HUNGER GAMES, it takes place in a fictional USA that has devised a new way of dealing with hatred, crime, and murder. MURDER becomes legalized by the state for a period of time, in order to weed out the sick, poor or marginalized. (Referring to war perhaps?) However, the Purge is a good premise, with an execution devoid of humanity or artistic subtlety.  Hunger Games' characters have meaning and context; they evolve and develop during the film. THE PURGE might have worked well, as a 15 minute film (Its hardly even 80 minutes long, as it is). If they could have had the family all cozy, interspliced with various "freak out" murders, while condensing all the running around and hiding, I could have liked the film. Or, if the film showed how unjust the PURGE was to elderly, disabled, or the poor, I would have enjoyed that. (Instead of having these ideas narrated by the "nightly news" on their TV sets.) But the film had all the depth and insight of a cheap "shoot 'em up" video game. Unfortunately, I had to fast forward repeatedly during an 80 minute long film, barely watching more than 15-20 minutes of the movie.  Like a video game, much of the film had characters running around with a gun in their hands,  thru long dark hallways and big rooms, looking to shoot someone.  The invaders who were shot, were neither tragic figures, nor arch villains. They were at best ciphers.

The major plot hole, was when the 11 year old kid disarmed the security system, in order to be a nice guy for a stranger.  And after he caused all the trouble, the family never said a single word to condemn his behavior. (EXTREMELY unbelievable!) The basic premise of this movie could have been interesting....with better acting and a better storyline.  Instead, the movie is a thinly veiled vehicle for anti-white bigotry and propaganda. The movie is pretty heavy handed in implying that people are universally evil but, limited to one night a year, they behave themselves the rest of the year.  There is some minor suggestion that this may have worked simply because Americans, enraged at all the crime, simply genocide the criminal element every year while law enforcement looks the other way.  In fact, the title, "The Purge" has a double meaning.  It is supposed to mean the cathartic purge of evil through one night of sheer wickedness a year.  But a purge could mean a selecting out and eliminating of a problematic element (and has been used that way multiple times in history).  Here is where the movie screws it up.  Those doing the purging are the very caricature of evil and the movie goes out of its way to portray white people, especially rich white people as either cowards who hide behind fortress walls or unreasonable psychopaths.  The victim is, of course black.  Since that is almost the exact opposite of how things are in real life, only this is like the millionth time today, some media has rammed that lie down my throat, the movie gets an F where its poor acting and tendency to drag would give it a D.  D minus, actually for the random scene where the girls boyfriend hides out in the home and attempts to murder her father for no particular reason whatsoever (because... you know....the way to impress a girl is by killing her family).  The magic black guy is, of course, a war hero.  And never mind the fact that black people refuse combat roles for the most part in every war ever waged.

This movie could have not been a total wash if they simply eliminated the black guy as the victim and not went there.  It could, in fact, have been a great movie, if they made him a criminal scumbag, hiding out from the one night a year when law abiding folk are allowed to hunt him down like a dog in revenge.  Throw in a few surviving family of one of his victims.

The movie has nowhere near the honesty, courage or even chutzpah to go there.  But it does far worse than play it safe.  It is a blatant attempt to lie about who is doing evil in our society.  In the end, it fails even at that.....being so heavy handed and unrealistic as to be unbelievable.....revealing its agenda and leaving an overall bad taste in the mouth.
